title: Ronnie O'Sullivan's English Open opponent Jamie O'Neill back after '4 or 5 year party'
text:
Ronnie O’Sullivan faces Jamie O’Neill in Crawley (Picture: VCG via Getty Images)

Jamie O’Neill has been handed the task of facing Ronnie O’Sullivan in the English Open first round, and ditching his party lifestyle has afforded him that opportunity.

The 33-year-old is back on the World Snooker tour this year after coming through Q School in May, securing his fourth stint in the game as a professional.

This season is the first since 2013/14 that O’Neill has been competing as a pro and he put his return to the main tour down to a renewed focus on the sport, and turning down a few nights out.

‘A lot’s happened in the last 4 or 5 years, I’ve basically had a party,’ O’Neill told World Snooker after regaining his spot on the tour. ‘But I decided to get my head down about a year or go and get in all the comps I can, basically get used to winning.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘I did that, started to pick up a few comps, it came together after getting my nut down.

‘I’ve still got a long way to go with the cuing but I feel like I’ve improved, I’m probably a better player now than when I was last on the tour, practice harder, I don’t go out as much. I’ve just got to give it a good crack this time and see what happens.

‘I’m going to have a few beers, though, I’ve stayed off the beers for a while but I’ll have a few tonight and they’ll taste smooth as silk.’

Jamie O’Neill has a big task on his hands against the Rocket (Picture: EPSB/Twitter)

It has been a tough start back to life on tour for O’Neill, and also a very unlucky one as he was one of a number of players forced to withdraw from the Riga Masters due to a flight being grounded thanks to a storm.

O’Neill had beaten world number 10 Barry Hawkins in the qualification round for the tournament and was due to face Sam Craigie in the last 64 but had to pull out.

That victory over Hawkins has been his only win of the season so far and the clash with Craigie would have been only his eighth appearance in the main stages of a ranking event, so it was a major disappointment for O’Neill.

However, he will have the chance to cause a sensational upset in Crawley on Monday night when he takes on the Rocket on his first ever appearance at the English Open.
